title: Shop Safety!
description: Get Shop certified!

title: Creative Coding with Processing
description: This workshop will give you an introduction to the basic principles of creative coding with Processing. Processing is an open-source coding platform used by designers and developers to create interactive installations, data visualizations, software tools, and much much more.

title: exploring biomimicry
description: This 2-hour workshop on biomimicry will address nature as inspiration for design and technological solutions. We will consider the biological and natural world, and work hands on to create quick prototypes using paper, pen, and some building materials, on topics that might include re-designing social networks, mapping urban spaces, and re-defining user interfaces.

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Getting Started with Raspberry Pi
description: Learn the fundamentals of Raspberry Pi, the $35 learning computer and why people are so excited about it. This workshop will be a demo of the platform and a Raspberry Pi is not needed to participate.

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.

title: Intro to the Soft Lab
description: This workshop will introduce you to the basics of using ITP’s soft lab resources — specifically the sewing machines, the embroidery machine, and the vinyl cutter.  This will mostly be a demo session, so no materials are required!

title: Quantified Self: Tools, Trends, and Applications
description: When Forbes called 2013 “the year of the Quantified Self” at CES it became clear that this is no longer a niche field just for life loggers. In this session I will go through the history of the quantified self (QS) movement, the existing apps/devices available, ways to hack together your own tools, trends in the industry, and discuss areas that are still untouched by this phenomenon that seems to be the new buzz word of 2013. A year and a half ago my life changed when I began tracking what I ate and how I felt, eventually leading me to cut gluten and dairy out of my diet. Since then I have become immersed in the QS field, helping to co-organize numerous Quantified Self Meetups here in NY, experimenting with dozens of QS tools/apps, and hacking together numerous quantified self tools of my own and in groups with others. By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of the existing QS landscape, be aware of industries ripe for QS development, and be primed with some easy ways to hack together their own projects and tools.

title: Introduction to the Arduino Yún
description: So you want to network your microcontroller. These days, you’ve got a lot of options. Here’s the latest from Arduino, the Yún. This board has the heart of an Arduino Leonardo attached to a WiFi-equipped Linux processor.

title: Smart Dust – is it inevitable?
description: I’d argue that the era of the commodity beige box is coming to an end, and the days of the general purpose computer are almost over. Most people never needed or wanted a computer, and they’re going to be happy with more limited devices optimised for a single, or a few, purposes so long as those devices just work. Today the black rectangle has replaced the beige box, but don’t get too comfortable, because it won’t last as long. Today’s cellphones and tablets are transition devices, dependent on our current level of technological progress, and around you everyday objects are already becoming smarter.

title: Sensing our surroundings : log sensor data using arduino
description: This hands on workshop will address visualizing data input from Arduino. The context of the class will be based around open source semi-autonomous sailing robots called Protei, designed to sense & clean oceans. After a brief introduction about Protei project, the remainder of the session will be devoted to understanding the very basics of sensing & exploring the environment through collecting & visualizing data using remote sensors, including sensors such as photocells, potentiometers, and more complex ones like barometers, GPS, and accelerometers.

title: <del>Gettin’ jiggy with the GSM shield</del>
description: The Arduino GSM shield allows you to make and receive voice calls, send and receive SMS messages, and send data over a cellular network.

title: Really Big Video Part 1
description: This session will introduce Big Building Mapping and Video Projection. I will begin by showing examples of site-specific and video mapping pieces and then we will map a real building using a spatial scan in Mad Mapper. For homework each camper will get a scan to work from and some tips on how to create giant projections. Part 2 of the session will allow campers to showcase their mapped work projected 3 stories tall on an actual building on broadway.

title: Intro to Python
description: This workshop will serve as an introduction to the Python programming language.  Topics covered will include:

title: Crazy Data Circles with d3.js
Re-wiring for Re-cycling
description: Physical Computing strikes me as a unique opportunity to recycle materials destined for landfill while creating unique objects and experiences. I’ve recently come to realize that a large part of my increased comfort level with electronics derives from a shift in perspective; no longer do I simply see a lonely rusted bike wheel littering my neighborhood, but raw materials such as spokes that make great axles for rotating propellers and mirrors. The VCR I found outside my friend’s studio became a drawer of motors, buttons, and a tape reader that now scans discarded video tapes in tandem with that bike tire! So for this session I’d like to lead a conceptual and hands on workshop in which we dream up ways to use discarded electronics (which I will provide). What inventive ways will we think to use an air mattress pump? A robotic aerosol sprayer? A game involving a levitating object? The possibilities are vast and can only improve with a conceptual shift concerning everyday objects.

title: Prototype to Performance, Will it survive onstage??
description: So you just built this fancy “whatchamacallit” and it works perfectly on the bench, but what happens when you have to hand it off to someone else to be used in live performance, in the desert, on a mountain, in a forest or really anywhere else other than a nice neat controlled environment?  Build your device to be performance proof…

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description: So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We’ll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions.

title: XBee Basics Workshop
description: Learn the basics of XBee wireless communication with 802.15.4 (Series 1) radios. We’ll demystify the various different types of radios and wireless networks, work through a basic wireless serial connection and talk about direct pin access. I’ll provide loaner XBees, but if you’d like to bring your own, we’ll be using XBee Series 1 with Sparkfun’s XBee explorer. Also, please download Coolterm and FTDI drivers if you haven’t already.

title: Introduction to Distributed Sensor Networks
description: Sensors are the future of distributed data. General-purpose computing is dissipating and becoming increasingly embedded into our lives. We will soon begin to move in a sea of data, our movements monitored and our environments measured and adjusted to our preferences, without need for direct intervention.

title: Wearable and Mobile Accessories
description: Kate Hartman and Shawn Van Every will give a tour through some of the recent wireless and wearable platforms and products that are emerging and give a workshop on how we might prototype some ideas of our own.

title: Disruptive design for future environments: Fashioning personal protection with smart fabrics
Aerial Photography of Fresh Kills Landfill
description: Fresh Kills is one of the most infamous landfills in the United States containing all of New York city’s waste for over 50 years.  Visible from space and as large as the Great Wall of China, Fresh Kills is a New York secret located in Staten Island and currently being converted into a public park over the next thirty years.  Join us for a field trip to this epic landscape to discover the final resting place of our trash and experiment with aerial photography using kites and large helium balloons.  WIth these grassroots mapping techniques, we can begin to develop a high resolution map of the landfill, investigate vegetation growth and begin to better understand what happens to the things we throw away.

title: Midi, Sysex, and the Arduino. New tricks for an old dog.
description: unable to attend this day but would love to get notes on this afterwards if anyone can share

title: Making Fireworks in Three.js
description: Make a neat fireworks animation just in time for the Fourth of July!

title: Introduction to the Brooklyn Museum Collection API
description: Francis Guy – Winter Scene in Brooklyn
